content: The "Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act of 2017" authorizes the National Computer Forensics Institute within the Department of Homeland Security to disseminate information on cyber and electronic crime prevention and train law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judges. The National Computer Forensics Institute, authorized by the "Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act of 2017," educates and trains law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judges on cyber and electronic crimes, investigative methods, forensic examinations, prosecutorial and judicial challenges, and network intrusion incident response. The National Computer Forensics Institute, established under the "Strengthening State and Local Cyber Crime Fighting Act of 2017," provides training to law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judges on obtaining, processing, and admitting digital evidence in court. The Institute also shares expertise on cyber and electronic crime with law enforcement and prosecutors, and may supply necessary computer equipment for investigations and forensic examinations. The National Computer Forensics Institute facilitates the expansion of Electronic Crime Task Forces by adding State, local, tribal, and territorial law enforcement officers trained at the Institute. Funding for this initiative is allocated from the United States Secret Service budget for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a new item after section 821. SEC. 3. PREVENTION, INVESTIGATION, AND PROSECUTION OF ECONOMIC, HIGH TECHNOLOGY, INTERNET, AND OTHER WHITE COLLAR CRIME. Title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include a new section on the prevention, investigation, and prosecution of white collar crime. The National White Collar Crime Control Act of 2017 authorizes the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance to provide training and assistance to improve the identification, investigation, and prosecution of white collar crimes, including high-tech and cyber crimes. The National White Collar Crime Control Act of 2017 authorizes training for law enforcement agencies to combat high-tech, economic, and internet-based crimes, including cyber and financial fraud, child exploitation, and intellectual property crimes. The National White Collar Crime Control Act of 2017 authorizes training for law enforcement agencies to combat high-tech crimes, including cyber and financial fraud, child exploitation, and intellectual property crimes. This includes providing assistance and training on methodologies to prevent, detect, and respond to crimes, managing electronic and financial crime evidence, improving criminal justice agency responses, enhancing criminal intelligence analysis, conducting cyber and financial crime investigations, and ensuring protections for privacy and civil liberties. The National White Collar Crime Control Act of 2017 authorizes programs for law enforcement agencies to combat various criminal activities through training, intelligence-focused policing strategies, and investigative support services at the state and local levels. The National White Collar Crime Control Act of 2017 authorizes programs for law enforcement agencies to combat criminal activities through training, research support, partnerships, and information dissemination to the public. It also includes establishing national training and research centers to provide services for State and local criminal justice agencies. The National White Collar Crime Control Act of 2017 authorizes programs for law enforcement agencies to develop and comply with privacy, civil rights, and civil liberties policies. Eligibility for grants requires submission of an application to the Bureau of Justice Assistance by entities with experience in providing training and resources to law enforcement personnel. Enforcement officers, investigators, auditors, and prosecutors at the state and local government levels, as well as online, are eligible for awards under this part. The Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance will establish necessary rules and regulations, including those for application submission and review. $13,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 to implement specific acts related to crime control and intellectual property.
